children.title: Law-based Constraints
notes: Constraints derived from empirical laws that dictate limits based on natural laws.

children.title: Body Size Constraints in Animals
notes: Limited by the square-cube law, law of gravity, and musculoskeletal strength, determining the maximum and minimum size of an animal.

children.title: Mathematical Constraints
notes: Constraints based on mathematical properties or principles.

children.title: KÃ¶nigsberg Bridge Problem
notes: Topological features of the bridge system constrain the available walking paths, making certain routes impossible.

children.title: Causal Constraints
notes: Constraints that are causal in nature, structuring and limiting the outcomes of a process.

children.title: Spatial Location Constraints
notes: Examples include riverbanks guiding rivers, and roadways constraining traffic movement.

children.title: Constitutional Changes Constraints
notes: Guiding changes in the makeup or constitution of an entity over time, such as metabolic pathways in biology.

children.title: Physical Structure Constraints
notes: Physical barriers such as blood vessels, nerve tracts, and lymph vessels guiding or restricting the flow of biological processes.

children.title: Large-Scale Social Forces
notes: Structural causes in sociology and politics, such as poverty, racism, and gender inequality, limiting behaviors and decisions of individuals.

children.title: Anatomic Barriers in Medical Context
notes: Physical entities like tumors, vascular routes, and tissue malformations influencing medical outcomes through larger-scale physical forces.
